dataservice-documentation.connecting-heading1: There are multiple ways to connect to your data service including JDBC, ODBC, OData, REST or SOAP.
dataservice-documentation.connecting-heading2: This is meant to give you a starting point. Please see the full documentation for more details.
dataservice-documentation.connecting-java1: To connect to your service using JDBC, use the following connection string in your client: {{connection_string}}
dataservice-documentation.connecting-java2: Before you can make a JDBC connection to the data service, you must include the Teiid driver jar file in your application's classpath. For a Java application to connect to a JDBC source, it needs a URL, user-id, and password. To connect to your VDB all you need is a URL and any additional optional properties that you would like to set. A JDBC connection can be obtained through the Teiid driver 'org.teiid.jdbc.TeiidDriver' with the URL syntax of jdbc:teiid:{VDB-Name}@mm(s)://{host name}:{port}. You can add optional properties at the end of the URL using a semi-colon(;) name=value format. For example 'jdbc:teiid:{VDB-Name}@mm(s)://{host name}:{port};autoCommitTxn=DETECT'. Check out Client Developer's guide for all the optional connection properties in your URL. See the sample code tab for an example of how to make JDBC connection.
dataservice-documentation.connecting-odata1: Deployed services are accessible using OData URLs. This service is accessible via: {{url}}.
dataservice-documentation.connecting-odata2: The service is protected using HTTP Basic security and requires the user to have a role of 'odata' defined for OData access. For more information on the OData protocol, please see http://odata.org
dataservice-documentation.connecting-odbc: Open Database Connectivity (ODBC) is a standard database access method developed by the SQL Access group in 1992. ODBC, just like JDBC in Java, allows consistent client access regardless of which database management system (DBMS) is handling the data. ODBC uses a driver to translate the application's data queries into commands that the DBMS understands. For this to work, both the application and the DBMS must be ODBC-compliant -- that is, the application must be capable of issuing ODBC commands and the DBMS must be capable of responding to them.Teiid can provide ODBC access to deployed VDBs in the Teiid runtime through PostgreSQL's ODBC driver. This is possible because Teiid has a PostgreSQL server emulation layer accessible via socket clients. By default, ODBC is enabled and running on on port 35432.

help.java-sample: 'This example illustrates how to connect to and query a data service from a Java client. The Teiid driver needs to be included in the client classpath.'
help.javascript-sample: 'This example uses jquery to retrieve an OData result set. See http://jquery.com for details.'
help.python-sample: 'This example uses Python to query the data service via an OData URL. You will need to update the username and password accordingly.'
help.php-sample: 'This example uses curl to query the data service via an OData URL. The appropriate Base64 encoded authentication string will need to be added.'
help.node-sample: 'This example uses the o.js javascript library available for node. See http://www.npmjs.com/package/odata for details.'

dataservice-test.enterQueryMsg: Enter an SQL query to test the Data Service
dataservice-test.failedDeploymentMsg: The Data Service could not be deployed:

help.endpointSubmit:
'

This URL is formed using the OData specification. It can be copied into a new browser window to return the results in xml format or append ?format=json to the URL for JSON.

Click the Submit button to display the results in a formatted table.

'
help.select:
'

Choose the view from which results should be sought.

Select a limit to curtail the number of results returned

'
help.columns: Select the columns to be included in the results.
help.where:
'

Create where clauses for filtering the results based on the values in each tuple.

Use the + button to add new where clauses (clauses are and-ed together) and remove them with the - buttons.

'
help.orderBy: Sort the results by column in ascending or descending order.
help.resultsTable:
'

Use the column headers to sort the results or filter them by entering values.

Results are paginated in blocks of 25 and can be scrolled through with the controls at the foot of the table.

'
help.resultsRaw:
'

The raw data as returned from the odata teiid service in json format.

'
help.sqlSearch:
'

Use the Teiid dialect of SQL to construct a query that interrogates the data service for data results.

Use the record limit to limit the number of results returned.

Set the starting record index to fetch a subset of results starting at the given row index.

'
